import React from 'react' import Header from '../components/Header' import Footer from '../components/Footer' import poster from '../images/poster.png' import granular from '../images/granular.png' import './UxHci.css' function UxHci() { return ( <>

UX Design and Human-Computer-Interaction additions for the Sonyc app.



The SONYC project is accompanied by a mobile app that allows users to monitor and report Air Quality information. In order to communicate the results of the SONYC research so our non-scientific audience can more easily understand how the data collected affects them, we used metaphors like presenting PM2.5 information collected as “cigarettes smoked”. A rule of thumb is that one cigarette per day is the rough equivalent of a PM2.5 level of 22 μg/m3. Users are able to see PM2.5 levels in their area within a 24-hour period with a line that shows the acceptable limits set by EPA. Recommendations provide users action items on what to do when the air in their area gets worse. Users will get notifications to log the current air quality conditions in their area into a journal. Data from these manual logs can be used to establish a pattern about AQ in the area. AQ Knowledge Database for users to learn more about PM & AQI Interactions of the app can be viewed below. In case, I have hosted an app on a different domain, you can check it out here: https://www.sonyc-visualizer.org/ I haven't finished it fully yet, but if you have any suggestions on the content, let me know.




Undergraduate Summer Research Program Poster{' '}




Why Noise?

Noise pollution is one of the topmost quality of life issues for urban residents in the United States. It has been estimated that 9 out of 10 adults in New York City (NYC) are exposed to excessive noise levels, i.e. beyond the limit of what the EPA considers to be harmful. When applied to U.S. cities of more than 4 million inhabitants, such estimates extend to over 72 million urban residents. The objectives of SONYC are to create technological solutions for: (1) the systematic, constant monitoring of noise pollution at city scale; (2) the accurate description of acoustic environments in terms of its composing sources; (3) broadening citizen participation in noise reporting and mitigation; and (4) enabling city agencies to take effective, information-driven action for noise mitigation.





) } export default UxHci
